sentences: Derek Johnson, Jr., better known by his stage name Derek Minor and former stage name PRo, (born December 16, 1984) is an American Christian hip hop artist, record producer, entrepreneur, actor, and screenwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: He co-founded the hip-hop record label Reflection Music Group (RMG) with Doc Watson, and signed to Reach Records in a joint venture between the two labels in 2011.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2012, Johnson announced that he had changed his stage name from Pro to Derek Minor.
section: N/A

sentences: In 2014, he announced that as his two-album contract with Reach was complete, he would no longer be publishing releases through that label.
section: N/A

sentences: He is a founding member of the hip-hop group R.M.G. on Reflection, and was formerly a member of the Reach hip-hop collective 116 Clique.
section: N/A

sentences: Johnson has released six studio albums and six mixtapes as a solo artist, as well as one studio album each with the groups R.M.G. and 116 Clique.
section: N/A

sentences: His second studio album, Redemption, charted at No. 8 on the Billboard Gospel chart and No. 31 on the Billboard Top Christian chart.
section: N/A

sentences: His third studio album, Dying to Live, debuted at No. 66 on the Billboard 200, No. 1 on the Top Christian chart, No. 2 on the Gospel Albums chart, No. 7 on the Top Independent Albums chart, and No. 11 on the Top Rap chart.
section: N/A

sentences: His fourth album, Minorville, released in 2013 debuted at No. 5 on Billboard's Rap Albums chart and No. 7 on the Top Christian chart.
section: N/A

sentences: He partnered with Entertainment One to release his fifth album, Empire, that debuted at No. 6 on the Billboard Rap Albums chart and No. 1 on the Top Christian chart.
section: N/A

sentences: His sixth album, Reflection, entered the Billboard Rap Albums chart at No. 5 and the Top Christian chart at No. 7.
section: N/A

sentences: Reflection's single "Change the World" featuring Hollyn reached No. 1 on Billboard's Hot AC/CHR chart.
section: N/A

sentences: Johnson's film and television work includes the three-part webseries "Dying to Live" and the short documentary films Redemption and Welcome to the Family Documentary.
section: N/A

sentences: Johnson also was featured as the title character in the video game Altered Pro, released under Reach Records.

== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Early ===
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Derek Johnson, Jr. was born in Pontiac, Michigan on December 16, 1984, but at a young age relocated to Middle Tennessee with his mother.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: His relationship with his birth father was distant, and his relationship with his stepfather became increasingly tense.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Furthermore, Johnson's stepfather was a drug user while his mother was a strict, devout Christian with a rigorous work schedule and homelife.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Johnson decided to help his mother by becoming rich through either education or music.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Johnson had grown up with music, as Gospel songs were played at his house and his mother was in choir and sang around the city.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Johnson's father, a jazz musician, provided the inspiration for him to go into music.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: When Johnson was 12, he visited his father in the summer and started rapping about God and adolescence, with his father producing beats with an Ensoniq ASR-10.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Johnson was also introduced to DJ Quik that summer, and went home with piles of tapes.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: After visiting to Middle Tennessee State University at age 15, Johnson decided to enroll in the music program there and make his ambitions a reality.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: His mother helped him by buying him production equipment, and by the time he entered college, Johnson was in a rap duo and got a job to pay for studio time.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: He graduated in 2006 with a bachelor's degree in Recording Industry Management.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Johnson recalls that before he turned 21 he used a bunk bed as a mic stand and signed a record deal with an independent label.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: While on the label, he released a mix tape, but the company folded and his life took a turn for the worse.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Removed from his strict home environment, Johnson rebelled.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: He pursued music, women and money until '"the season of death"' shook up his life.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: Within a short time span, Johnson lost his grandfather, grandmother and godmother.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===

sentences: This loss sparked a realization of the fleeting nature of life, and Johnson decided to dedicate his life and talents to God.
section: == Life and career == | === Early ===
== Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: Reflection Music Group (2008–2010)
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===
== Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: Johnson co-founded Reflection Music Group, then-called Christ Like Entertainment, with his friend Doc Watson, who he met while working on a second mixtape, Transformers.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: Johnson released his debut album The Blackout in 2008.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: According to DaSouth.com, the "braggidocious, swagtastic approach" that Johnson took on the album met with controversy in the Christian hip hop community.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: Johnson took a break from rapping, and was challenged and influenced by a new friend, BJ, that he met at his new church in Memphis, Tennessee, and was further challenged by Christian hip-hop artist Lecrae.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: Johnson reflected that his first album was mostly about haters and how good an emcee he was, and was convinced that it should have been more focused on God.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: In January 2010, Johnson released the mixtape PSA, which he considers his first full-length installment of "mature" Christian music.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: That year, Johnson went on the "Urban Missionary Tour" with Thi'sl, k-Drama, and J'Son, including a stop in the United Kingdom.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: In preparation for his second studio album, Redemption, Johnson wrote a short autobiographical film entitled "Redemption", and it was released as a web film in May.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: The album Redemption was released July 13, 2010, and peaked at No. 8 on the Billboard Top Gospel Albums and No. 31 on the Top Christian Albums charts.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: This release was followed by an announcement in August that Johnson would be featured as a special guest on the 116 Clique "Unashamed 2010" tour, which ran October through November.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

sentences: Also in August, Johnson received a write-up in Jet and was featured on the front page of the magazine's website.
section: == Life and career == | === Reflection Music Group (2008–2010) ===

== Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On January 25, 2011, Reach Records announced that it had signed Johnson as a joint venture with Reflection Music Group, and the same day Johnson released the single "116", featuring KB.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On March 8, Johnson released the mixtape PSA: Vol. 2.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On July 10, Johnson announced the launch of a three-part webseries "Dying to Live" to promote his upcoming studio album of the same name.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: In the months of August and October, Pro toured with 116 Clique as part of the group's "Man Up" campaign.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On August 9, Reach Records released the web game Altered Pro, a zombie game based on the Sega classic Altered Beast.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: The full-length studio album, Dying to Live, was released on August 23.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: The album debuted at No. 1 on the Christian Albums chart, No. 2 on the Gospel Albums chart, No. 7 on the Independent Albums, No. 11 on the Rap Albums chart and No. 66 on the Billboard 200.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: The album was also the featured banner on the iTunes homepage as well in the Christian & Religious and Hip Hop/Rap departments.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: In September, Johnson performed at the 2011 Flavor Fest, and on September 27, 2011, the album Man Up by 116 Clique was released.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: In October, Johnson was included with Braille and 116 Clique as some of the artists in the iTunes Indie Spotlight for hip hop music.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: In February 2012, Reflection Music Group announced the formation of the hip-hop group R.M.G., consisting of the artists Pro, Canon, Tony Tillman (formerly known as Brothatone), and Chad Jones (formerly known as Conviction).
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: With this announcement came the release of R.M.G.'s debut single "Geeked Up" on February 21.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On March 21, the group released an online documentary film entitled "Welcome to the Family Documentary" in preparation for its debut album Welcome to the Family, which was released March 27.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On March 17, 2012, Johnson performed at the 2012 South by Southwest festival as part of the Reach Records showcase along with Lecrae, Trip Lee, Tedashii, Andy Mineo, and KB.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On August 6, 2012, Johnson revealed the cover art for his upcoming mixtape, PSA Vol.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: 3: Who Is Derek Minor?, and with it revealed that he had changed his stage name from Pro to Derek Minor.

sentences: Come Alive" tour.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On November 8, 2012, South by Southwest announced that Reach Records would again hold a showcase with its entire roster, including Derek Minor, in 2013.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: In an interview with Rapzilla on May 5, 2013, Kyle Dettman, video director for Reach Records, revealed that Reach Records is preparing promotional material for Derek Minor's upcoming album Minorville.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On June 6, 2013, Minor released a lyric video for a single from Minorville, "Dear Mr. Christian" featuring Dee-1 and Lecrae, followed by an actual release of the single the next day.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: Later, on June 21, Reach Records released the album cover for Minorville by a video showing the album cover making-process, and also announced the release date, September 10, 2013.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: The promotion for the album continued on July 2, when Minor dropped a teaser video for a track called "In God We Trust" featuring Thi'sl.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: The album debuted at No. 40 on the Billboard 200, No. 1 on the Gospel Albums Chart, No. 2 on the Christian Albums Chart, No. 6 on the Independent Albums Chart and No. 6 on the Rap Albums Chart, making it his best chart performing album to date.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: On March 18, 2014, Rapzilla announced that Derek Minor had parted ways with Reach Records, as his two-album contract with Reach had expired.
section: == Life and career == | === Reach Records and name change (2011–2013) ===

sentences: Minor was quoted, "I've grown as an artist, business owner and a man.

sentences: The beauty of the relationship we've established is that business wasn't its primary agenda and I'm excited to see what the future holds for both RMG and Reach."
